content.text: At a football club, season tickets are sold for seated areas and for standing areas
The cost of season tickets are in the ratio seated : standing = 5 : 3
The cost of a season ticket for the standing area is \(45
Find the cost of a season ticket for the seated area
In 2021, the value of the team's players was \(2.65 million
In 2022 this value has decreased by \(12\frac{0}{0}\)
Find the value in 2022
The number of people at a football match is 1455
This is \(6.25\%\) of the total number of people allowed in the stadium
Find the total number of people allowed in the stadium
The average attendance increased exponentially by \(4\%\) each year for the three years from 2016 to 2019
In 2019 the average attendance was 1631
Find the average attendance for 2016
The number of family season tickets sold is \(x\)
Write an expression, in terms of \(x\), for the number of individual season tickets sold
In 2019, the number of family season tickets sold increases by 12 and the number of individual season tickets sold decreases by 26
Complete the table by writing expressions, in terms of \(x\), for the number of tickets sold each year
In 2019, the number of individual season tickets sold is 3 times the number of family season tickets sold
Write an equation in \(x\) and solve it to find the number of family tickets sold in 2018
Another club sells season tickets for individuals and for families
In 2018, the number of season tickets sold is in the ratio family : individual = 2 : 7
Complete the table
On the grid on the opposite page, draw the graph of \(V = x^{2}(9 - x)\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 9\)
Find the values of \(x\) when the volume of the cuboid is \(44 \mathrm{cm}^3\)
The volume, \(V \mathrm{cm}^3\), of the cuboid is \(V = x^2 (9 - x)\)
The table shows some values of \(V\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 9\)
Show that the total surface area of the cuboid is \((36x - 2x^2)\mathrm{cm}^2.\)
Find the surface area when the volume of the cuboid is a maximum
All the lengths in this question are measured in centimetres
The diagram shows a solid cuboid with a square base
Calculate an estimate of the mean
Ann uses this frequency table for the same data
There is a different interval for the final group
Without calculating an estimate of the mean for this data, find the difference between Ann's and Kai's estimate of the mean
You must show all your working
A histogram is drawn showing the information in **Kai's** frequency table
The height of the block for the interval \(200 < d \leqslant 300\) is \(2.6 \text{cm}\)
Calculate the height of the block for each of the following intervals
One car is picked at random
Find the probability that the car has travelled more than \(300\mathrm{km}\)
both cars have travelled \(150\mathrm{km}\) or less,
one car has travelled more than \(200\mathrm{km}\) and the other car has travelled \(100\mathrm{km}\) or less
Two of the 200 cars are picked at random
Find the probability that
Kai and Ann carry out a survey on the distances travelled, in kilometres, by 200 cars
Kai completes this frequency table for the data collected
shape \(A\) onto shape \(B\),
shape \(A\) onto shape \(C\),
shape \(A\) onto shape \(D\)
Describe fully the **single** transformation that maps
On the grid, draw the image of shape \(A\) after a reflection in the line \(y = x + 8\)
Calculate the acceleration of the car during the first 18 seconds
In the first 40 seconds the car travelled \(134\mathrm{m}\) more than the bus
Calculate the constant speed, \(v\), of the bus
The diagram shows the speed–time graph for part of a journey for two vehicles, a car and a bus
Time (seconds)
A train takes 10 minutes 30 seconds to travel \(16 240 \mathrm{m}\)
Calculate the average speed of the train
Give your answer in kilometres per hour
Solve
Factorise
Write as a single fraction in its simplest form
Find an expression for \(m\) in terms of \(n\)
Solve by factorisation
\(y\) is directly proportional to \((x + 3)^{3}\)
Find \(x\) when \(y = 108\)
g is inversely proportional to the square of \(d\)
When \(d\) is halved, the value of g is multiplied by a factor \(n\)
Find \(n\)
Expand and simplify
Find the derivative, \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\), of \(y = 3x^{2} + 4x - 1\)
Calculate angle \(QPR.\)
Find the shortest distance from \(Q\) to \(PR.\)
Calculate the length \(AG.\)
Calculate the angle between \(AG\) and the base \(ABCD\)
The diagram shows a cuboid
The diagram shows the positions of a lighthouse, \(L\), and two ships, \(K\) and \(M\)
The bearing of \(L\) from \(K\) is \(155^{\circ}\) and \(KL = 112 \text{km}\)
The bearing of \(K\) from \(M\) is \(010^{\circ}\) and angle \(KML = 96^{\circ}\)
Find the bearing and distance of ship \(M\) from the lighthouse, \(L\)
Bearing
Distance .........km
Find the coordinates of \(B\)
Show that the equation of the perpendicular bisector of \(AB\) is \(2y + 5x = 74\)
The perpendicular bisector of \(AB\) passes through the point \(N\)
The point \(N\) has coordinates \((2, n)\)
Find the value of \(n\)
Points \(A\), \(M\) and \(N\) form a triangle
Find the area of the triangle
\(AB\) is a line with midpoint \(M\)
\(A\) is the point (2, 3) and \(M\) is the point (12, 7)
On the diagram, sketch the graph of \(y = \sin x\) for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 360^{\circ}\)
Solve the equation \(5 \sin x + 4 = 0\) for \(0^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 360^{\circ}\)
The lengths of the sides of a triangle are \(11.4\mathrm{cm}\), \(14.8\mathrm{cm}\) and \(15.7\mathrm{cm}\), all correct to 1 decimal place
Calculate the upper bound of the perimeter of the triangle
The diagram shows a circle, radius \(15.6\mathrm{cm}\)
The angle of the minor sector is \(150^{\circ}\)
Calculate the area of the minor sector
The diagram shows a circle, radius \(r\mathrm{cm}\) and minor sector angle \(x^{\circ}\)
The **perimeter** of the major sector is three times the **perimeter** of the minor sector
Show that \(x = \frac{90(\pi - 2)}{\pi}\)
Find the two possible values of \(m\)
Find, in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) and/or \(\mathbf{c}\), in their simplest form,
\(OABC\) is a parallelogram
\(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OC} = \mathbf{c}\)
\(P\) is the point on \(C B\) such that \(C P:P B = 3:1\)
\(OP\) and \(AB\) are extended to meet at \(Q\)
Find the position vector of \(Q\)
\(\overrightarrow{OP}\)
